eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Health
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Manage health points and damage, including a protective shield and armor.
description: Manage health points including a protective shield and armor. Health can be assigned to players, enemies, NPCs, or even inanimate objects such as breaking doors and mining rocks.
Damage calculations are performed in this order:
Incoming Damage -> Is Damage Cooldown active? -> Chance to Dodge -> Flat Damage Reduction -> Percent Damage Reduction -> Damage to Shield -> Damage to Health
How to use:
- Set desired values in behavior properties
- To apply damage use “Apply damage to an object”
- To heal health, use “Heal object” action
- To activate the shield, use “Activate shield” action
- Health and shield regeneration will happen automatically based on properties
Tips:
- While damage cooldown is active, no damage will be applied to health or shield (the object is invincible)
- Try using the “Blink” extension while damage cooldown is active
- Use the “Is just damaged” or "Is just healed" conditions to trigger sound and visual effects
Health properties:
- Starting health points
- Maximum health points. Use "0" for no maximum
- Damage cooldown (seconds) Use "0" for no cooldown
- Rate of health regeneration (points per second)
- Delay before health regeneration starts after being hit (seconds)
- Allow heals to increase health above max health (regen will never exceed max health)
Shield properties:
- Max shield points. Use "0" for no maximum
- Duration of shield (seconds) Use "0" to make shield permanent
- Rate of shield regeneration (points per second)
- Delay before shield regeneration starts after being hit (seconds)
- Block excess damage when shield is broken (yes/no)
The top-down RPG example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-rpg)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading and overheating.
description: This extension allows objects to fire bullets.
It handles:
- Cooldown between shots
- Firing multiple bullets at a time ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fire-bullet))
- Ammo management
- Overheat
It can be used for:
- Twin-stick shooters ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://conviction-of-gun-dude-desktop))
- Shoot'em up ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-shooter))
A simple example shows how to make firing patterns ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://firing-patterns)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: THNK_Local
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: An inter-tab local machine only adapter for easy testing in previews.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: This THNK adapter uses the `BroadcastChannel` feature of browsers that allows multiple tabs of a browser to communicate. This allows for locally connecting multiple open game instances, and is very handy for testing with previews. Comes with an option to start multiple preview windows at once automatically!

inlineCode: const logger = new gdjs.Logger("THNK - Local Testing Adapter");
"This browser does not support the local adapter - please try using another adapter! (Prepare for an error)"
(e) => logger.error("An error occured while sending a message!", e)

eventsFunctions.description: Starts a local testing server.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: THNK_P2P
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: The P2P networking support module for the THNK framework.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: Allows to host a THNK server on a P2P connection, and for other peers to connect to it via the server's P2P ID.

inlineCode: const logger = new gdjs.Logger("THNK - P2P Adapter");
"Tried to send a message on an unestablished connection!"

eventsFunctions.description: Starts a scene as a remote scene server that connected P2P peers can join. The current game will also switch and connect to the game. If you switch to another scene or start another remote scene over P2P, the local server will be shut down and connected peers disconnected.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Start a remote scene over P2P
eventsFunctions.name: StartServer

parameters.description: The scene to start as a THNK P2P server
parameters.name: scene

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: THNK
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A framework to build authoritative multiplayer games.
description: # The THNK Framework
A framework for building authoritative games with GDevelop. In a single click, you can turn your THNK game multiplayer!
Games made with THNK multiplayer will, through a mix of imposed rules and a rich set of optimisations & performant features, run fast as state-of-the-art multiplayer games.

This - the core THNK extension - allows you to build any game with the authoritative server-client pattern. They will not be multiplayer: by default, all THNK games are single player and will run fine without being connected to anyone else. When/if you want to add multiplayer, THNK servers can be started and connected to in 1 action via the different THNK adapter extensions.
Learn more at https://thnk.cloud/ ;)

eventsFunctions.description: Triggered once when the dedicated server starts up. Returns false if the initialisation is not successful, and crashes the server. Don't forget to log a message in the console before returning false to see why your server crashes!
eventsFunctions.name: OnServerStart

events.comment:
By default, no special action is done here, and true is returned for signaling a successful initialisation.
Return false instead of true to crash the server at the beginnign if something is wrong.
You could use this for:
- Starting all the remote scenes you need, for example, in the case of an MMO, where you want the players to have one remote scene for each "room"/scene.
- Running basic diagnostics like verifying accesses to required external services, for example firebase.
- Send yourself some analytics to see how many users start their own dedicated server.
- Prevent running the server on a system that doesn't meet certain requirements.
- Logging a welcome message when starting up the server :D

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers when a client just joined the dedicated server.
eventsFunctions.fullName: A client has connected to the server
eventsFunctions.name: OnConnection

events.comment:
By default, do nothing. Return false to prevent the connection.
You can use this to:
- Update presence informations on your database
- Prevent unauthenticated players from joining
- Only let certain beta testers connect to the server at all

eventsFunctions.description: Triggered whenever a client asks for a remote scene to be created. Return false if the creation of the room was not allowed, to tell the client. Remove the "start a remote scene" action to disable creating new rooms alltogether.
eventsFunctions.fullName: A client requests a remote scene to be created
eventsFunctions.name: OnRSCreationRequest
eventsFunctions.sentence: A client request a remote scene to be created

events.comment:
By default, allow all remote scene creations and do as the client says.
You can use this: 
- To prevent making other remote scenes out of a scene (for example in an MMORPG where all rooms are in common, people cannot make their own private version of a room).
- To prevent users that do not have the required privilieges to create certain types of rooms.

parameters: "Remote scene '" + GetArgumentAsString("remote_scene_name") + "' based on scene '" + GetArgumentAsString("base_scene_name") + "' created"

parameters.description: The name of the scene the remote scene should be based on
parameters.name: base_scene_name

eventsFunctions.description: Triggered whenever a client asks to connect to a remote scene. Return false if the creation of the room was not allowed, to tell the client. Remove the "start a remote scene" action to disable creating new rooms alltogether.
eventsFunctions.fullName: A client requests to join a remote scene
eventsFunctions.name: OnRSJoinRequest
eventsFunctions.sentence: A client request to join a remote scene

events.comment:
By default, allow joining all rooms.
You can use this: 
- To make a set of remote scenes only available to beta testers.
- To prevent joining any remote scenes without an approved account.
- To lock a banned player out of joining remote scenes.

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers when a client just disconnected from the dedicated server.
eventsFunctions.fullName: A client has disconnected from the server
eventsFunctions.name: OnDisconnection

events.comment:
By default, do nothing.
You can use this to:
- Update presence informations on your database
- Apply sanctions to a player if they disconnected at a moment they were not allowed to

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if the game is currently running a server. Do not use this to delimit server code, as this ignores the server tick rate. Rather, use this in client code to display additional options reseerved to the host
eventsFunctions.name: IsServer
eventsFunctions.sentence: A server is running on this client

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers if the current scene is in singleplayer mode. When switching to a scene normally (without connecting to a remote scene), the game runs in this mode and doesn't run any netcode, while still emulating the THNK framework to allow the game to run as it would otherwise. This condition can be used to disable features that only make sense in multiplayer, like a chat, in the case the game is not being played in multiplayer.
eventsFunctions.name: IsSinglePlayer

inlineCode: // If we are neither client nor server, we are playing singleplayer.

eventsFunctions.description: The condition to put before the start of client code. This ensures that dedicated servers do not run client-only code.
eventsFunctions.name: StartClientCode

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if a connection to a server/remote scene is currently in progress
eventsFunctions.name: ConnectingToServer

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if the connection to the server has failed. If the connection succeeded, the game would have switched to the remote scene.
eventsFunctions.name: ConnectionFailed
eventsFunctions.sentence: Connection to the server has failed

events.comment: UNIMPLEMENTED

eventsFunctions.description: Gives the error code returned by the server while attempting a connection
eventsFunctions.name: ServerConnectionError

events.comment: UNIMPLEMENTED

eventsFunctions.description: Sends a message to the server.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Send a message to the server
eventsFunctions.name: SendMessage
eventsFunctions.sentence: Send message _PARAM1_ to the server (extra data: _PARAM2_)

parameters.description: (Optional) A variable with extra data for the server
parameters.name: extra_data

eventsFunctions.description: The condition to put before the start of server code. Ensures that events meant for the server are only run when needed.
eventsFunctions.name: StartServerCode

inlineCode: // The server is active, only run server code if it is time to.
// The server is innactive. Only run the server code if client mode is innactive too, as that'd mean singleplayer.

eventsFunctions.description: Give the server a target of ticks per second. A tick is when the server side code is executed. Default is 20.
eventsFunctions.name: SetServerTickRate

eventsFunctions.description: Sets the currently picked player to another one, by its ID
eventsFunctions.name: PickPlayerByID

parameters.description: The ID of the picked player
parameters.name: PlayerID

eventsFunctions.description: Returns the ID of the player that is currently picked. The picked player can be changed by some conditions (like OnMessage) and actions, and will be used to know who to target with other actions (like MoveToRemoteScene) and conditions. Use THNK::PlayerID() to get your own player ID.
eventsFunctions.name: PickedPlayer

eventsFunctions.description: Links an object to the currently selected player.
eventsFunctions.name: LinkObjectToPlayer

parameters.description: The object to link to the current player
parameters.name: Object

eventsFunctions.description: Pick the instances of the object that are linked to the currently picked player.
eventsFunctions.name: UseLinkedObjects
eventsFunctions.sentence: Pick instances of _PARAM1_ linked to the player

parameters.description: The object to pick linked instances for
parameters.name: Object

eventsFunctions.description: Triggered when a message from the client has been received.
eventsFunctions.name: OnMessage

parameters.description: (Optional) A variable with extra data from the client
parameters.name: extra_data

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers when a client has connected to the scene.
eventsFunctions.name: OnClientConnect

events.comment: In singleplayer, there is only one player. Trigger their connection event one at the start and that's it.

eventsFunctions.description: Triggers when a client has disconnected from the scene.
eventsFunctions.name: OnClientDisconnect

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Makes the THNK framework automatically synchronize instances of an object across clients. To be used for objects like moving terrain, player objects, etc: objects that will display the same for every user.
Not to be used on objects unique to a single user, like an inventory menu. Prefer to send over variables the contents of the inventory and display it with non-synchronized objects.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SynchronizedObject

inlineCode: // Object was not created by the server but the game is in client mode, delete it.
// Workaround a GDevelop bug that creates a ghost object when deleting an object at the beginning of the scene
